results.title: Not wanted: pollution
results.brief_description: The forest industry is the main export industry in Sweden, but it is also the main polluter of the water courses in the country. In 1969 Sweden made new stringent environmental protection laws, and in 1970 the pulp industry began pollution control projects. Investment requirements in the pollution control sector are considerable and in order to obtain the best possible basis for these investments, a research project - The Forest Industries’ Water and Air Pollution Research Laboratory - was started. Some examples of pollution control measures in the pulp industry are shown.

results.title: Not wanted on voyage
results.creator_credit: Hugh Alexander, Eric Thompson and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: An account of the work being done by the Commonwealth Plant Quarantine officers to prevent the introduction of dangerous insect pests and plant diseases into this country from overseas. In addition to checking cargoes on arrival at Australian ports, quarantine officers extend their vigilance to overseas loading points in their efforts to keep Australia free of diseases prevalent in other countries.

results.title: Not quite Jerusalem
results.brief_description: Set in a kibbutz, Joanne Pacula and Sam Robards are cast as an Isreali girl and an American volunteer, who meet and fall in love on the kibbutz. Gila (Pacula) is a hardnosed and foulmouthed “kibbutz-nik” who tones down her language when she finds love. Cast includes Kevin McNally, Todd Graff and Selina Cadell.

results.title: Not my problem
results.creator_credit: Ann Vracin, Dan Bessie and Barr Films
results.brief_description: Dave is the usual gregarious 16 year-old. Baseball, homework and Susan, his current love, take most of his time. But when Susan suspects she is pregnant, Dave won’t alter his schedule to discuss the problem. As he tells his friends, “If she does get herself pregnant, it’s not my problem.” Only Jim, one of Dave’s friends, tries to convince him that it is his problem…and his and Susan’s. When Susan comes to the baseball field to talk with Dave, the reality of the situation suddenly becomes clear. They have some very important decisions to make…together.

results.title: Not just a spectator
results.creator_credit: Bill Latto and Town and Country Productions
results.brief_description: It is a mistake to think that physically disabled people cannot play sport. They can actively compete in many sports and recreational activities, and greatly benefit from the special classes geared to their needs. Shows how the trained instructors, helpers and general public can help and encourage them.

results.title: Not at random
results.brief_description: World population is now 3.6 billion. The human race has doubled its numbers since 1920. It may have doubled again by the end of the century. This is a report on the population problem in Southeast Asia showing the various dimensions of the problem, including the different attitudes of people in cities and rural areas toward birth control and family planning. A solution to the population crisis must be found before any real attempt can be made to overcome many of the major problems facing the world today so as to ensure the quality of life and social justice of all.

results.title: Not a bedroom war
results.creator_credit: Kay Pavlou, Anna Grieve, Anne Deveson, Anne Deveson Productions and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description: A Global Forum of Women was held in Dublin in 1992, a gathering of women leaders from around the world, assessing together the gains already made by feminism and the ground still to be covered to eliminate prejudice against women. The women discussed the need for, and importance of, a diversity of women in positions of leadership to serve as role models, the problems of balancing career and family, and women as an economic and political force. Those interviewed include Mary Robinson, President of Ireland, Dr Anne Summers, women’s adviser to the Australian Prime Minister, Betty Friedan, author of “The Feminine Mystique”, Bella Abzug, former US Congresswoman, Devaki Jain, Indian economist, Dame Jocelyn Barrow, UK broadcaster, Iola Mathews of the ACTU, and Ruth Bamela Engo-Tjega from Cameroon who works for the UN.
